content: Hey all! Our meeting is in ~15 minutes, but I wanted to note that I had just posted the initial PR for the blog post - https://github.com/rust-lang/blog.rust-lang.org/pull/822 - which ended up shorter than our usual ones. Feedback definitely appreciated.
@T-release meeting!
ok
so, as you saw, posted the release blog post a bit ago, definitely likely to receive more iteration but didn't want to get it up too late
I'm not actually sure if there's much more to discuss today
Thanks for volunteering :smile:
I guess I have a thing
I didn't have time yet to write a reply to it, but I'd also love input from the rest of the team on https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-forge/pull/517#discussion_r586067905
but actual discussion can be done async on github
/end
do we have engagement stats on twitter vs. the blog?
maybe even just a referrer breakdown on the blog posts
Not to my knowledge
we don't have analytics on the blog at all
tweets get a lot of engadgement though
that can be done with plain server-side logging, no?
but if we don't have it, we don't
so I'm kind of butting in here, but my impression from the github thread is that simulacrum is unsure why announcing and publishing the release have to be simultaneous
like, it seems ok for the tweet to be a day late

cuviper said:

but if we don't have it, we don't

no, we're on github pages which doesn't expose it
ah

Joshua Nelson said:

so I'm kind of butting in here, but my impression from the github thread is that simulacrum is unsure why announcing and publishing the release have to be simultaneous

I would personally see it as having the blog post be a day later

Well I think my opinion is that we should share the Twitter credentials with other members on this team or from community to post the tweets. I do think itâ€™s a bit important, and should be done, but I also understand that one more switch to flick in a process is draining.
an entire day late would be rather unprofessional
a few hours, meh
twitter is currently one of the three official venues where we announce it
no, we announce on 3 according to the latest iteration: users, twitter, blog
forgot about URLO as usual :sweat_smile:

I'm very hesitant to share Twitter credentials more broadly than they are now, personally. I am trying to understand the connection between blog post and tweet, and I admit I don't really see it; what is the goal with making sure people know of the post immediately?

I think it's important that there is some official announcement with details about the release, so users can verify it's not some rogue release or whatever, but why that has to be on all platforms I'm not sure I understand
viewed from another direction, I think it would be totally reasonable for every blog post to get a tweet
it's today's weak RSS
Like the entire rust-lang org is extremely online, and tweet regularly, there has someone who we can trust and would want to tweet. :smile:
I think that may be reasonable, but there's no real reason people have to find out instantly?
Like, my RSS reader can take a few hours to propagate
if the problem is dealing with 1password and logging into twitter and 2fa and such during the release process, I don't think that's really accurate
I still don't understand why it must happen immediately
If it happens within a 4-hour period, which it will -- we have enough people with access -- that seems fine

(twitter basically never logs you out, so you could login into a firefox container and during the release process just click https://twitter.com/compose/tweet and copy/paste the template, without any other step)
Frankly, for me, it's a lot of added stress to do that. Maybe that's unfounded, but I don't regularly tweet, and I don't want to be logged in to our official twitter all the time
do you not use tweetdeck for access?
what's the concern about letting an API do it?
If we had the API setup, then sure
but we ... don't?
you said in the PR that you were hesitant
oh, well, I just mean that we don't have a great place necessarily for that to happen, but it's not a huge deal - just added overhead

@_Jonas Schievink [he/him]|211727 said:

do you not use tweetdeck for access?

if this refers to me, no, I don't really use twitter at all
anyway, it sounds like this is not really moving productively at this point

Yeah, not to do the classic engineer solution trying to automate everything. If we had a tweet command available in the private project leads channel or a dedicated Twitter channel here, would that address your concern of permissions?

I don't think there is a reason why it has to happen, but the release tweet is usually the one quote tweeted or when the discussion happen on our release, and it gets a ton of engadgement (I can provide numbers in private)
I think neither is a good option; I'd prefer to go with the RSS-like feed @cuviper suggested if we do engineer something
Yeah, but I'm not saying it need not happen
I'm saying: we don't need it to happen immediately
then the @rustlang tweet is not going to be the one quote tweeted or where the discussion happens on twitter
OK? I guess I'm confused why that'd be a problem, discussion with or without the tweet seems about the same in my eyes, really, but :shrug:
So with the rss feed, would the tweet be picked up from new metadata? Essentially making the tweet part of writing the blog post?
Well, we have already a template in the PR I think? Or somewhere
release blog posts are already specially annotated as release: true

XAMPPRocky said:

So with the rss feed, would the tweet be picked up from new metadata? Essentially making the tweet part of writing the blog post?

in the long term having something like tweet: in the blog post frontmatter would be awesome (that way it could also be reused for other blog posts)
but in any case, I guess I just don't see this as a big deal, especially when it hasn't been for the last ~5 years
well, in the past 5 years we almost always tweeted at the same time
Right, without... any work to do that? If we're happy with status quo, I am too
But the changes in the PR suggested something stronger, I think
the person doing the release wasn't the one tweeting, but it happened
I guess I'm trying to see the problem being addressed by adding more stringent requirements on the release process itself

simulacrum said:

But the changes in the PR suggested something stronger, I think

I can reword, but my intent in the PR is that if nobody (me or steve) is online at that time the release person should post the tweet, otherwise they should just ping steve or possibly me
most of the times it shouldn't happen, but if nobody happens to be online I'd still like to see a tweet go out
I also donâ€™t know what the foundationâ€™s plans are right now, but this is also a problem solved by money. Paying someone part time to tweet on behalf of the rust-lang twitter.

OK, well, it seems like we can drop the tweet bit from this PR maybe, since it has other good changes; we can then discuss it separately. We seem to be in alignment that status quo is already a success.
like, even pinging at the start of the release process to ask if someone is available to tweet would be a good start
That seems fine to me
in the near past we pinged for example steve right after the blog post got out, and we can't expect him to be instantly ready to tweet
Anyway, I need to run, but we can discuss more async on the PR, I guess, or maybe schedule some time. Not sure.
Thanks all!
